Title: Can all points in the plane be represented like this?
Content: Solving a task regaring affine geometry, I've come across a problem: Is it  true that, for every point $(x,y)\in \mathbb{R}^2$, there  exist $t\in \mathbb{R}, \alpha\in[0,2\pi]$, such that $$x = t\cos\alpha + \sin \alpha \\ y = t\sin\alpha + \cos \alpha?$$ I don't have any idea how to prove this or find a counterexample. All hints appreciated!
